We need to make sure that the cookie is set the same as the server:
server overcloud-controller-0.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.22:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-0.internalapi.localdomain fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
server overcloud-controller-1.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.25:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-1.internalapi.localdomain fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
server overcloud-controller-2.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.12:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-2.internalapi.localdomain fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2

The problem here is that the cookie is being inserted into the response
by haproxy so that we have session persistence. When logging to horizon
we want the session to be persistent and go to the same backend server.
When haproxy sees a match for the cookie, it does just that. The cookie
value will should match the server name. Prior to this fix
each server was matching on the same cookie ($::hostname) which is not
correct.

Tested by connecting to horizon's VIP and shutting off horizon on each
controller node one at the time. Observed that after each stop, the
correct cookie from the remaining servers was sent to the browser.

NB: it was not a straight cherry-pick due to missing change
I1a68771cc7be7fb2b32abbad81db7890bd2c5502 in ocata (missing
haproxy/horizon_endpoint.pp)

Backport tested by hand by applying this patch and observing that the
horizon stanza looks correct like in OSP13:
listen horizon
  bind 10.0.0.9:80 transparent
  bind 172.17.0.15:80 transparent
  mode http
  cookie SERVERID insert indirect nocache
  option forwardfor
  option httpchk
  server overcloud-controller-0.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.17:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-0.internalapi.localdomain fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
  server overcloud-controller-1.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.19:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-1.internalapi.localdomain fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
  server overcloud-controller-2.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.25:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-2.internalapi.localdomain fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2

Closes-Bug: #1738453
Change-Id: Ieb9cf3c6a8373df288a73ff2dacfc9d0b09e675a
"}]
commit_message:
Give horizon's stanza in haproxy a per-server cookie

Currently our haproxy.cfg stanza for horizon looks like the following:
server overcloud-controller-0.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.22:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-0 fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
server overcloud-controller-1.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.25:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-0 fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
server overcloud-controller-2.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.12:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-0 fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2

We need to make sure that the cookie is set the same as the server:
server overcloud-controller-0.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.22:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-0.internalapi.localdomain fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
server overcloud-controller-1.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.25:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-1.internalapi.localdomain fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
server overcloud-controller-2.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.12:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-2.internalapi.localdomain fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2

The problem here is that the cookie is being inserted into the response
by haproxy so that we have session persistence. When logging to horizon
we want the session to be persistent and go to the same backend server.
When haproxy sees a match for the cookie, it does just that. The cookie
value will should match the server name. Prior to this fix
each server was matching on the same cookie ($::hostname) which is not
correct.

Tested by connecting to horizon's VIP and shutting off horizon on each
controller node one at the time. Observed that after each stop, the
correct cookie from the remaining servers was sent to the browser.

NB: it was not a straight cherry-pick due to missing change
I1a68771cc7be7fb2b32abbad81db7890bd2c5502 in ocata (missing
haproxy/horizon_endpoint.pp)

Backport tested by hand by applying this patch and observing that the
horizon stanza looks correct like in OSP13:
listen horizon
  bind 10.0.0.9:80 transparent
  bind 172.17.0.15:80 transparent
  mode http
  cookie SERVERID insert indirect nocache
  option forwardfor
  option httpchk
  server overcloud-controller-0.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.17:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-0.internalapi.localdomain fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
  server overcloud-controller-1.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.19:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-1.internalapi.localdomain fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
  server overcloud-controller-2.internalapi.localdomain 172.17.0.25:80 check cookie overcloud-controller-2.internalapi.localdomain fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2

Closes-Bug: #1738453
Change-Id: Ieb9cf3c6a8373df288a73ff2dacfc9d0b09e675a

As far as a new role for this feature is required (to be hosted with non-instance-ha compute role), I think the ComputeInstanceHA service should be added to all compute instances. And control it using the role-specific service parameter [1]. 

And -1 to remove the deprecated definitions for the new role.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/tripleo-docs/latest/install/advanced_deployment/role_specific_parameters.html'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2018-02-21 08:44:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > As far as a new role for this feature is required (to be hosted
 > with non-instance-ha compute role), I think the ComputeInstanceHA
 > service should be added to all compute instances. And control it
 > using the role-specific service parameter [1].
 > 
 > And -1 to remove the deprecated definitions for the new role.
 > 
 > [1] https://docs.openstack.org/tripleo-docs/latest/install/advanced_deployment/role_specific_parameters.html

Thanks for [1] I had not yet looked at it, it's good that we added this feature.
I am not yet sure I'll be able to use it though as I am not sure what to do with the PacemakerRemote service. If I add it to all Compute instances then due to the fact that we enable it explicitly in environments/docker-ha.yaml and environment/puppet-pacemaker.yaml we'd get a pacemaker remote running on all compute nodes, which is not what we want and I'm a bit concerned about removing PacemakerRemote from those two env files. Thoughts?

ComputeInstanceHA does not have the same issue and would be perfect for your suggestion."}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2018-02-22 08:04:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2018-02-22 09:02:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2018-02-22 19:15:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Add a ComputeInstanceHA role

We add a ComputeInstanceHA so that using -e
environments/compute-instanceha.yaml does not require customizing roles
by hand and we can rely on the 'openstack overcloud role generate'
command.

Change-Id: I613b7653c9cb6f8e6f368066c4d881e682d62308

commit_message:
Temporarily disable osc-functional-devstack-tips

There is a deeper issue related to versions and sibling installation in
the period between a release and the first release in the next cycle on
the master branch. A fix is in progress for that, but it will take a few
more days to get it in place.

In the meantime, the workaround is actually to just cut a release of
openstacksdk. The floating ip patch (next) is a pretty important bug, so
disable the osc-functional-devstack-tips job for a second so that we can
land the floating ip fix. Then we can cut a new release and re-enable
the job.

A revert of this patch follows.

Change-Id: Idec38e3017db57ea56b3bce860a261abee7076d7

commit_message:
Add throughput limits that scale per-GB

This allows new values in QoS specs:
 - read_bytes_sec_per_gb
 - write_bytes_sec_per_gb
 - total_bytes_sec_per_gb

The bytes value specifed in the QoS spec is multiplied
by the size of the volume in initialize_connection,
and the result is passed along like a standard <x>_bytes_sec
QoS value.

Change-Id: Iafc22d37c4c50515d9f6cf1144ea25847c90f75d

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-21 19:57:18.000000000', 'message': "Fix manila logging rabbitmq password in debug mode

Manila will display the rabbitmq password if debugging is enabled.
This patch will ensure that the rabbitmq password is no longer
displayed in the connection log for Manila when debugging is
enabled by looking for the rabbitmq key and not printing it.

There should likely be an effort to utilize Oslo's secret flag for
options to truly fix this issue for this and other sensitive options.

Change-Id: I97cc88354d9b54057350c70c4742055197540d1a
Closes-Bug: 1750074
(cherry picked from commit 05e4f14ea1fbc7ce61c8f57a082080d09c63e357)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix manila logging rabbitmq password in debug mode

Manila will display the rabbitmq password if debugging is enabled.
This patch will ensure that the rabbitmq password is no longer
displayed in the connection log for Manila when debugging is
enabled by looking for the rabbitmq key and not printing it.

There should likely be an effort to utilize Oslo's secret flag for
options to truly fix this issue for this and other sensitive options.

Change-Id: I97cc88354d9b54057350c70c4742055197540d1a
Closes-Bug: 1750074
(cherry picked from commit 05e4f14ea1fbc7ce61c8f57a082080d09c63e357)

commit_message:
Solving permission errors due to directory ownership on NFS

We do the same work as the GlusterfsBackupDriver, uses chgrp+chmod to set
proper permissions on the directories if needs be.

Change-Id: Ic57c122311039af159c0cfc083e6e9349702d1e4
Closes-Bug: #1715456
(cherry picked from commit dd4c31f527e2c8f93fdfa55fe6713e0e32d94cc9)

[{'created': '2018-03-01 19:02:44.000000000', 'message': 'Import Zuul unittests

Add the unittests in-tree and convert them as Zuul v3 native tests so
that they can be modified locally.

This adds a new job running on Ubuntu and an experimental CentOS-7 one.

Change-Id: Ib43e40280411623fda84f2068958b64a17cdc3dc
'}]
commit_message:
Import Zuul unittests

Add the unittests in-tree and convert them as Zuul v3 native tests so
that they can be modified locally.

This adds a new job running on Ubuntu and an experimental CentOS-7 one.

Change-Id: Ib43e40280411623fda84f2068958b64a17cdc3dc

This commit adds irrelevant-files for this job.

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2017-11-26 16:12:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2017-11-27 20:37:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 23.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-01-23 15:00:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23: Code-Review-1

I don't understand what this is for. Having a global lower constraints or requirements setting is going to be incompatible with projects being able to have their own lower bounds set for their dependencies, which is the point of the work to stop syncing requirements across projects in the first place. Each project should have its *own* set of lower bounds and lower constraints and those should be tested within the project (which means no integration testing until we have isolation between the components installed by devstack to support that)."}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2018-01-23 15:39:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

This is useful for sanity checking g-r bumps alone (e.g. transitive version bumps when you require now Y>=V+1, you also need to update Z to Z>=+1) and it allows identify lower bounds that fell out of reality (for example one of the core openstack project requires at least a particular version but did not bump the min)'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2018-01-23 16:06:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 24.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-01-24 07:15:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: Code-Review+2

This stage is fine, if only for testing our tooling, but what we do with this info is more concerning and may need some guidance from governace (what we support as openstack).'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-01-25 20:51:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

commit_message:
Add a global coinstallable lower-requirements set

This is generated from the lower bounds of g-r.txt
and to be maintained manually. There is a variant
of check-uc called check-lc added that will verify
those dependencies to be coinstallable and passing
consistency checks.

Change-Id: I99ad9f0b1d6c150bee6d6d35f84a74e99ab849b8

commit_message:
Make CNI Registry Plugin namespace aware

As with the k8sCNIRegistryPlugin the watching is for the
complete node, instead of per pod and namespace, we need
to make registry information to account for the namespace
where the pod is created to differentiate between different
containers running on the same node, with the same name, but
in a different namespace

Related-Bug: 1731486
Change-Id: I26e1dec6ae613c5316a45f93563c4a015df59441

commit_message:
Move cni plugins to a common folder

This patch moves the cni plugins that were split between api.py,
main.py and daemon/service.py to have then in a unified path.

Change-Id: Ief15e3f8a722237649dd5a1fb8c4e26f51143072

set the port it serves on.

subject: Kill rsync coros when lockup detector tries to kill the process
messages:
[{'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-02-26 12:26:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-02-26 16:42:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1 Code-Review-2

Yeah, this can kill the process but it looks to make a bunch of <defunct> processes so we shouldn't get this merged with (at least) current version."}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-02-26 16:44:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ah... the reason why the zombie processes are remaining is the parent replicator won't be dead to call restart on the replicator process."}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-02-27 10:21:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-02-27 10:30:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-02-27 10:31:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-02-27 10:35:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-02-27 10:35:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-02-27 10:38:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-02-27 10:43:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

So i turned down my [object-replicator] lockup_timeout = 1 (I also had to make sure I changed my interval = 1 and commented out # sync_method = ssync)

I also stopped rsyncd and replaced it with a black hole server [1] listening on 873

Then I uploaded and object and started my object-replicator and rm'd a part.

On master I saw logged:

    object-6016: Exception in top-level replication loop: Timeout (1s)

and lots of these:

    vagrant   4858  4827  0 10:35 ?        00:00:00 [rsync] <defunct>
    vagrant   4869  4827  0 10:35 ?        00:00:00 [rsync] <defunct>
    vagrant   4906  4827  0 10:36 ?        00:00:00 [rsync] <defunct>
    vagrant   4913  4827  0 10:36 ?        00:00:00 [rsync] <defunct>

With this change I get something different/better, logged:

    object-6016: Killing by lockup detector

... and no defunct rsync process!

WOMM!


1. https://gist.github.com/clayg/16212c0c3f058178c6cd6dec2e7cfe97"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-03 19:02:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

(4 comments)

Got https://review.openstack.org/#/c/549494/ as a follow-up to guard against the NameError and wait after killing.

I also put up https://review.openstack.org/#/c/549495/ to try killing if the terminate didn't seem to work, but it makes the test flakey -- it keeps getting killed by the top-level timeout at https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.17.0/swift/obj/replicator.py#L775-L776 which throws off the results :-/

Maybe someone smarter than me can think of a reasonable way to make that work?"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-03 22:00:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck

Pretty sure that failure was just flakiness, the same sort that gets exacerbated in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/549495/'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-26 12:26:49.000000000', 'message': "Kill rsync coros when lockup detector tries to kill the process

Because the replicator in the master doesn't propergate the kill
signal to the subprocess in the coroutine. With the behavior, the lockup
detector causes a lot of rsync processes evne it tries to reset the process.

This patch fixes the replicator kill rsync procs when the lockup detector
calls kill of eventlet threads.

Change-Id: Ifd14ce82de1f7ebb636d6131849e0fadb113a701
"}, {'created': '2018-02-27 10:21:40.000000000', 'message': "Kill rsync coros when lockup detector tries to kill the process

Because the replicator in the master doesn't propergate the kill
signal to the subprocess in the coroutine. With the behavior, the lockup
detector causes a lot of rsync processes even it tries to reset the process.

This patch fixes the replicator kill rsync procs when the lockup detector
calls kill of eventlet threads.

Change-Id: Ifd14ce82de1f7ebb636d6131849e0fadb113a701
"}, {'created': '2018-02-27 10:35:10.000000000', 'message': "Kill rsync coros when lockup detector tries to kill the process

Because the replicator in the master doesn't propergate the kill
signal to the subprocess in the coroutine. With the behavior, the lockup
detector causes a lot of rsync processes even it tries to reset the process.

This patch fixes the replicator kill rsync procs when the lockup detector
calls kill of eventlet threads.

Change-Id: Ifd14ce82de1f7ebb636d6131849e0fadb113a701
"}]
commit_message:
Kill rsync coros when lockup detector tries to kill the process

Because the replicator in the master doesn't propergate the kill
signal to the subprocess in the coroutine. With the behavior, the lockup
detector causes a lot of rsync processes even it tries to reset the process.

This patch fixes the replicator kill rsync procs when the lockup detector
calls kill of eventlet threads.

Change-Id: Ifd14ce82de1f7ebb636d6131849e0fadb113a701

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I7a4bcf340033a4e9f6ba50363df6955a1b96a3c4

subject: Make test_greater_with_offset not fail on py36
messages:
[{'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-03-02 03:07:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-02 11:02:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I wonder if we might prefer something like

 diff --git a/test/unit/common/test_utils.py b/test/unit/common/test_utils.py
 index 9fb543f51..04c77add6 100644
 --- a/test/unit/common/test_utils.py
 +++ b/test/unit/common/test_utils.py
 @@ -621,15 +621,16 @@ class TestTimestamp(unittest.TestCase):
                              '%r is not greater than %r given %r' % (
                                  timestamp, int(other), value))
  
 -    def test_greater_with_offset(self):
 -        now = time.time()
 +    def _test_greater_with_offset(self, now):
          older = now - 1
          test_values = (
              0, '0', 0.0, '0.0', '0000.0000', '000.000_000',
              1, '1', 1.1, '1.1', '1111.1111', '111.111_111',
              1402443346.935174, '1402443346.93517', '1402443346.935169_ffff',
 -            older, '%f' % older, '%f_0000ffff' % older,
 -            now, '%f' % now, '%f_00000000' % now,
 +            # Internally, timestamps are limited to 5 places after the decimal
 +            # so format like that here, too
 +            older, '%.5f' % older, '%.5f_0000ffff' % older,
 +            now, '%.5f' % now, '%.5f_00000000' % now,
          )
          for offset in range(1, 1000, 100):
              timestamp = utils.Timestamp(now, offset=offset)
 @@ -655,6 +656,20 @@ class TestTimestamp(unittest.TestCase):
                                  '%r is not greater than %r given %r' % (
                                      timestamp, int(other), value))
  
 +    def test_greater_with_offset(self):
 +        # Part 1: use the natural time of the Python. This is deliciously
 +        # unpredictable, but completely legitimate and realistic. Finds bugs!
 +        now = time.time()
 +        self._test_greater_with_offset(now)
 +        # Part 2: Same as above, but with a fixed time value that caused us
 +        # trouble in the past. Depending on how you convert the float to a
 +        # string, you might:
 +        #   - directly round to 5 places after the decimal and get a value
 +        #     like ...93, or
 +        #   - round to 6 places (getting ...935) then round to 5 and get ...94
 +        now = 1519830570.6949348
 +        self._test_greater_with_offset(now)
 +
      def test_smaller_no_offset(self):
          now = time.time()
          newer = now + 1

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-02 11:19:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Bonus fun with all of this:

 Python 2.7.6 (default, Oct 26 2016, 20:30:19)
 [GCC 4.8.4] on linux2
 Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
 >>> from swift.common.utils import Timestamp
 t=Timestamp.now(offset=8)
 >>> t=Timestamp.now(offset=8)
 >>> t
 1519989380.90474_0000000000000008
 >>> Timestamp(t)
 1519989380.90474_0000000000000008
 >>> Timestamp(t.internal)
 1519989380.90474_0000000000000008
 >>> Timestamp(t.internal.encode('ascii'))
 1519989380.90474_0000000000000008

Great! How about py3?

 Python 3.4.3 (default, Nov 17 2016, 01:08:31)
 [GCC 4.8.4] on linux
 Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
 >>> from swift.common.utils import Timestamp
 >>> t=Timestamp.now(offset=8)
 >>> t
 1519989380.17705_0000000000000008
 >>> Timestamp(t)
 1519989380.17705_0000000000000008
 >>> Timestamp(t.internal)
 1519989380.17705_0000000000000008
 >>> Timestamp(t.internal.encode('ascii'))
 Traceback (most recent call last):
   File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
   File "/vagrant/swift/swift/common/utils.py", line 951, in __init__
     self.timestamp = float(timestamp)
 ValueError: could not convert string to float: b'1519989380.17705_0000000000000008'

Hmm....

 Python 3.6.0 (default, Dec 28 2016, 09:49:20)
 [GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 8.0.0 (clang-800.0.42.1)] on darwin
 Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
 >>> from swift.common.utils import Timestamp
 >>> t=Timestamp.now(offset=8)
 >>> t
 1519989423.29971_0000000000000008
 >>> Timestamp(t)
 1519989423.29971_0000000000000008
 >>> Timestamp(t.internal)
 1519989423.29971_0000000000000008
 >>> Timestamp(t.internal.encode('ascii'))
 1519989423.29971_0000000000000000

Well crap. We went back in time!'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-03-02 11:23:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> -            older, '%f' % older, '%f_0000ffff' % older,
 > +            older, '%.5f' % older, '%.5f_0000ffff' % older,
 > Thoughts?

I thought that the point of the test was to test that if a client uses a plain %f, then things are okay too. It must be acceptable for anyone to supply %f (or, just about any fixed-point representation) in headers, and then we accept those and convert them into Timestamp(). Therefore, this better be tested. If you force the fraction field length to 5, then you are not testing what happens if it's longer, anymore."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-02 13:53:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> I thought that the point of the test was to test that if a client uses a plain %f

I think the %f is a red herring -- the primary reason we have them is to attach an offset, but the way that we *expect* consumers to add offsets is the Timestamp class, like

>>> x=Timestamp.now()
>>> y=Timestamp(x, offset=1)
>>> z=Timestamp(y, offset=1)
>>> x, y, z
(1519997937.68300_0000000000000000,
 1519997937.68300_0000000000000001,
 1519997937.68300_0000000000000002)'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-03-02 14:07:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-03 22:02:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

All right, yeah, I'm tired of seeing this make the py3 job flakey. I'll see about addressing some other Timestamp issues I noticed in a follow-up."}]

[{'created': '2018-03-02 03:07:54.000000000', 'message': "Make test_greater_with_offset not fail on py36

Reviewer, beware: we determined that the test was using the
facilities improperly. This patch adjusts the test but does
not fix the code under test.

The time.time() output looks like this:

[zaitcev@lembas swift-tsrep]$ python2
Python 2.7.14 (default, Dec 11 2017, 14:52:53)
[GCC 7.2.1 20170915 (Red Hat 7.2.1-2)] on linux2
>>> import time
>>> time.time()
1519861559.96239
>>> time.time()
1519861561.046204
>>> time.time()
1519861561.732341
>>>

(it's never beyond 6 digits on py2)

[zaitcev@lembas swift-tsrep]$ python3
Python 3.6.3 (default, Oct  9 2017, 12:07:10)
[GCC 7.2.1 20170915 (Red Hat 7.2.1-2)] on linux
>>> import time
>>> time.time()
1519861541.7662468
>>> time.time()
1519861542.893482
>>> time.time()
1519861546.56222
>>> time.time()
1519861547.3297756
>>>

(can go beyond 6 digits on py3)

When fraction is too long on py3, you get:

>>> now = 1519830570.6949349
>>> now
1519830570.6949348
>>> timestamp = Timestamp(now, offset=1)
>>> timestamp
1519830570.69493_0000000000000001
>>> value = '%f' % now
>>> value
'1519830570.694935'
>>> timestamp > value
False
>>>

Note that the test fails in exactly the same way on py2, if time.time()
returns enough digits. Therefore, rounding changes are not the culprit.

The real problem is the assumption that you can take a float T, print
it with '%f' into S, then do arithmetic on T to get O, convert S, T,
and O into Timestamp, then make comparisons. This does not work,
because rounding happens twice: once when you interpolate %f, and
then when you construct a Timestamp. The only valid operation is
to accept a timestamp (e.g. from X-Delete-At) as a floating point
number as a decimal string, and convert it once. Only then you can
do arithmetics to find the expiration.

Change-Id: Ie3b002abbd4734c675ee48a7535b8b846032f9d1
"}]
commit_message:
Make test_greater_with_offset not fail on py36

Reviewer, beware: we determined that the test was using the
facilities improperly. This patch adjusts the test but does
not fix the code under test.

The time.time() output looks like this:

[zaitcev@lembas swift-tsrep]$ python2
Python 2.7.14 (default, Dec 11 2017, 14:52:53)
[GCC 7.2.1 20170915 (Red Hat 7.2.1-2)] on linux2
>>> import time
>>> time.time()
1519861559.96239
>>> time.time()
1519861561.046204
>>> time.time()
1519861561.732341
>>>

(it's never beyond 6 digits on py2)

[zaitcev@lembas swift-tsrep]$ python3
Python 3.6.3 (default, Oct  9 2017, 12:07:10)
[GCC 7.2.1 20170915 (Red Hat 7.2.1-2)] on linux
>>> import time
>>> time.time()
1519861541.7662468
>>> time.time()
1519861542.893482
>>> time.time()
1519861546.56222
>>> time.time()
1519861547.3297756
>>>

(can go beyond 6 digits on py3)

When fraction is too long on py3, you get:

>>> now = 1519830570.6949349
>>> now
1519830570.6949348
>>> timestamp = Timestamp(now, offset=1)
>>> timestamp
1519830570.69493_0000000000000001
>>> value = '%f' % now
>>> value
'1519830570.694935'
>>> timestamp > value
False
>>>

Note that the test fails in exactly the same way on py2, if time.time()
returns enough digits. Therefore, rounding changes are not the culprit.

The real problem is the assumption that you can take a float T, print
it with '%f' into S, then do arithmetic on T to get O, convert S, T,
and O into Timestamp, then make comparisons. This does not work,
because rounding happens twice: once when you interpolate %f, and
then when you construct a Timestamp. The only valid operation is
to accept a timestamp (e.g. from X-Delete-At) as a floating point
number as a decimal string, and convert it once. Only then you can
do arithmetics to find the expiration.

Change-Id: Ie3b002abbd4734c675ee48a7535b8b846032f9d1

commit_message:
Add functional-py35 gate job

We have functional tests that run under py35, but they are not
currently run in gate. This adds the common job definition to
our locally defined list of tests to run.

Change-Id: Icf477415c7ac54bb007cacc1a1ba905e63fa2780

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-03 11:43:55.000000000', 'message': "Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I379cb24c302e1b388afa9b4186484b9c26a8ed43
"}]
commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I379cb24c302e1b388afa9b4186484b9c26a8ed43

The main change in this patch is to reorder first steps.
Before.
- create BDM,
- reserve volume in cinder.
After.
- reserve volume in cinder,
- create BDM.
I think it's not bad because the reserve is a call to remote service via HTTP
which would fail more likely.  Certainly, it can also fail in create
BDM but we can't be sure would it fail before or after creating in
DB. I tend to consider this call as atomic,  otherwise, it leads to
overcomplicated code here."}, {'account_id': 21813, 'date': '2016-08-25 08:37:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

intel-nfv-ci recheck'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2016-08-25 14:12:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

> The main change in this patch is to reorder first steps.
 > Before.
 > - create BDM,
 > - reserve volume in cinder.
 > After.
 > - reserve volume in cinder,
 > - create BDM.
 > I think it's not bad because the reserve is a call to remote
 > service via HTTP
 > which would fail more likely.  Certainly, it can also fail in
 > create
 > BDM but we can't be sure would it fail before or after creating in
 > DB. I tend to consider this call as atomic,  otherwise, it leads to
 > overcomplicated code here.

Yeah understood but the comments against PS#2 etc did suggest that this failure scenario would also be looked at by this change. I'd be happy to remove my -1 if you're not going to attempt this here and I'll look into a separate fix for this issue."}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2016-09-02 15:06:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

Hi Lee,

In my opinion, there is another way. 

Delete bdm records which have target isntance_uuid and volume id when bdm record is created.
This way keeps bdm record uniquely per volume_id and instance_uuid.
In my understanding, volume-multi-attach won't support multi attachments for same instance. (1 comment)

I'm ambivalent about this change. It probably fixes a bug in practise, but by the same measure while appearing simple it's actually pretty obtuse. It definitely doesn't have enough comments.

If these records are bugs, why can't we just prevent them from existing? How about a db migration which:

1. Swept the old ones.
2. Added a constraint to prevent creation of new ones.

The stack traces would then highlight the errors in code."}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2017-10-11 14:04:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23:

For posterity, update_or_create was added in change Iec08a33ec974a133ee5a620790af9308204a5f64 . Don't really like that either, as the code in question really should have enough context to know if it is updating or creating, and positively call one or the other."}, {'account_id': 8988, 'date': '2017-10-31 11:22:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23:

Hello Matthew,

Sorry for my late reply.
I can understand your opinion, and I don't have clear objections.

But, I think that the patch will be bigger than current one if I adopt your idea.
I'd like to continue current policy."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-02 15:57:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23: -Code-Review

Looks like we're taking another approach here now"}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2018-03-03 14:22:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: Code-Review-1

As discussed at PTG [1] we will be dropping this in favour of a nova-manage command in R to clean up these records and a schema migration in S to add a unique constraint between BDM uuid, instance uuid and volume id.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/nova-ptg-rocky - L564'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-03-03 22:25:13.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

So I think Lee's comment means this should be abandoned. Probably makes sense so current owners can "own" the resulting patch. Let me know if this isn't right and I can un-abandon this.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2016-03-09 19:25:07.000000000', 'message': "Do not reserve device before reserving the volum

Reserving a device means that we have to create a BDM reccord on the
compute node, as part of an RPC call. If we can't actually attach the
volume - it's pointless to create a BDM record which we will just delete
if the reservation in Cinder fails, but this also opens us up to leaking
BDM records, as there is a window where the API worker dying or RPC
timing out leaves us with a leaked BDM.

Change-Id: I0a7eacd0751d604b932e65a2671e2b88010b3560
Closes-bug: 1427060

"}, {'created': '2016-11-09 12:07:48.000000000', 'message': 'compute: Do not create bdm before reserving the volume

When attaching a volume to an instance the compute API previously
created a bdm record prior to calling Cinder to first check and then
reserve a volume. This introduced the risk of this bdm record not being
correctly cleaned up in the event of an API or RPC failure later in the
attach process.

To correct this the bdm is now only created after the volume is fully
reserved in Cinder. Failures to either create the bdm or to attach the
volume now also result in the bdm being removed and the volume
unreserved.

Change-Id: I0a7eacd0751d604b932e65a2671e2b88010b3560
Closes-bug: 1427060
Co-Authored-By: Andrey Volkov <avolkov@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Lee Yarwood <lyarwood@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2017-06-27 08:05:36.000000000', 'message': 'compute: Do not create bdms before successfully reserving a volume

When attaching a volume to an instance the compute API previously
created a bdm record before calling Cinder to first check and then
reserve a volume. This introduced the risk of this bdm record not being
correctly cleaned up in the event of an API or RPC failure later in the
attach process.

To correct this the bdm is now only created after the volume is fully
reserved in Cinder. Failures to then create the bdm or to attach the
volume now also result in the volume unreserved.
And remained bdm will be sweeped if the volume is re-attached to the
same instance.

'}, {'created': '2017-07-13 09:56:34.000000000', 'message': 'compute: Do not create bdms before successfully reserving a volume

When attaching a volume to an instance the compute API previously
created a bdm record before calling Cinder to first check and then
reserve a volume. This introduced the risk of this bdm record not being
correctly cleaned up in the event of an API or RPC failure later in the
attach process.

To correct this the bdm is now only created after the volume is fully
reserved in Cinder. Failures to then create the bdm or to attach the
volume now also result in the volume unreserved.
Any bdm records also created during the failure for the associated
instance and volume will be removed during the next attempt to attach.

Change-Id: I0a7eacd0751d604b932e65a2671e2b88010b3560
Closes-bug: 1427060

correctly cleaned up in the event of an API or RPC failure later in the
attach process.

To correct this, remained bdm will be sweeped if the volume is
re-attached to the same instance.
Bdm record of a specific volume should be only one by instances even
if volume multi-attach is used.

This fix doesn't cause side effects to volume multi attach.
Because volume multi attach doesn't allow multi attaching one volume
to one instance.

commit_message:
compute: Sweep duplicated bdm records

When attaching a volume to an instance the compute API previously
created a bdm record before calling Cinder to first check and then
reserve a volume. This introduced the risk of this bdm record not being
correctly cleaned up in the event of an API or RPC failure later in the
attach process.

To correct this, remained bdm will be sweeped if the volume is
re-attached to the same instance.
Bdm record of a specific volume should be only one by instances even
if volume multi-attach is used.

This fix doesn't cause side effects to volume multi attach.
Because volume multi attach doesn't allow multi attaching one volume
to one instance.

Change-Id: I0a7eacd0751d604b932e65a2671e2b88010b3560
Closes-bug: 1427060

subject: Set a route metric when static routes are used
messages: [{'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-03-03 05:32:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-03-03 12:37:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-03-03 21:51:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-03 05:32:38.000000000', 'message': 'Set a route metric when static routes are used

When using a static route we need to set a route metric to ensure the
priority of the routes being passed in. This change ensures we maintain
our expected interface and functionality should any static routes be
passed into the container.

Before the implementation of networkd, EIN would amend the main table
with the defined routes in the order they were written. However
systemd-networkd inserts the defined routes at the top of the default
table which can cause confusion and conflict. This change simply adds
a route metric to all defined routes and increments the metric integer
based on the list index which explicitly ensures all defined routes
are prioritized in the order in which they were written.

Change-Id: I13768580fbd926033fde4a74cbbf90b9eda24658
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Set a route metric when static routes are used

When using a static route we need to set a route metric to ensure the
priority of the routes being passed in. This change ensures we maintain
our expected interface and functionality should any static routes be
passed into the container.

Before the implementation of networkd, EIN would amend the main table
with the defined routes in the order they were written. However
systemd-networkd inserts the defined routes at the top of the default
table which can cause confusion and conflict. This change simply adds
a route metric to all defined routes and increments the metric integer
based on the list index which explicitly ensures all defined routes
are prioritized in the order in which they were written.

Change-Id: I13768580fbd926033fde4a74cbbf90b9eda24658
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Pin Docker-py version

Our gate is broken now due to Docker-py 3.1.0 [1].
Now APIClient.get_image return generators streaming the
raw binary data from the server‚Äôs response. It leads to
the exception [2].

The patch is just a temporary fix.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/538556/37/upper-constraints.txt
[2] http://logs.openstack.org/45/548445/8/check/zun-tempest-docker-sql/bf95c73/logs/testr_results.html.gz

Change-Id: I91af17f67eeb9986db258d7e8580bcd84de08ad6
Partial-Bug: #1753080

How does this relate to future projects in the other "strategic focus areas"?  We all still read "OpenStack" to mean the existing bits that are now in the Datacenter area.  Should we read "OpenStack" here to refer to "OPenStack Foundation projects" or just the Datacenter area projects?'}, {'account_id': 6088, 'date': '2018-02-15 18:21:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2018-02-15 18:26:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Here is the infra-manual change describing the process, for those curious: https://review.openstack.org/545077'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-02-15 18:27:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For Cinder drivers, it was my understanding that third party CI testing was allowed as long as it was for fully open source storage solutions (ceph, drdb, etc.). This does not explicitly state anything about that being a requirement here. I would feel better about this if we did make that a clear distinction to help avoid getting into the situation where we need to justify why we are allowing one project but not another. Or at least to give us clear guidelines and documented references to provide if we are in that situation.

Where does this fit with the OpenLab effort? It seems to have a lot of overlap.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-02-15 18:30:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2018-02-15 18:36:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sean, yes, I think Open-Source is still a requirement; I will revise this to add that.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2018-02-15 18:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17556, 'date': '2018-02-16 15:28:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I am wondering how our discussions around OpenLab (which uses Zuul) play into this? For example, we have already been working heavily with gophercloud[0], terraform[1], and kubernetes[2].

[0] https://github.com/gophercloud/gophercloud#thank-you
[1] https://github.com/terraform-providers/terraform-provider-openstack#thank-you
[2] https://github.com/theopenlab/openstack-cloud-controller-manager

At the previous PTG we engaged with Monty about the python SDK, Gilles about Ruby SDK, etc which got good feedback but I wonder if this makes efforts of OpenLab re SDKs meaningless? Just trying to understand a bit more the intent in light of other conversations.

Does this lessen the impact of the messaging around Zuul outside of OpenStack as a powerful CI tool?'}, {'account_id': 17556, 'date': '2018-02-16 15:29:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I am wondering how our discussions around OpenLab (which uses Zuul)
 > play into this? For example, we have already been working heavily
 > with gophercloud[0], terraform[1], and kubernetes[2].
 > 
 > [0] https://github.com/gophercloud/gophercloud#thank-you
 > [1] https://github.com/terraform-providers/terraform-provider-openstack#thank-you
 > [2] https://github.com/theopenlab/openstack-cloud-controller-manager
 > 
 > At the previous PTG we engaged with Monty about the python SDK,
 > Gilles about Ruby SDK, etc which got good feedback but I wonder if
 > this makes efforts of OpenLab re SDKs meaningless? Just trying to
 > understand a bit more the intent in light of other conversations.
 > 
 > Does this lessen the impact of the messaging around Zuul outside of
 > OpenStack as a powerful CI tool?

http://openlabtesting.org'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-02-16 16:02:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Worth keeping in mind this resolution isn't an _entitlement_ to open-source projects related to OpenStack saying they get free run of our infrastructure. It's meant to indicate that the TC doesn't _object_ to the Infra team reporting testing results to some projects outside the OpenStack shared infrastructure."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-02-16 16:24:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

Sounds good as a standalone thing.

But it also seems like there may be a separate conversation to have about how (potential) broader availability of openstack resources relates to openlab.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2018-02-16 16:26:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I certainly don't want to interfere with OpenLab because it's awesome.

In my mind, these are complementary efforts.  One of the purposes of
this proposal is for OpenStack projects to be able to use their
already-existing tests with other projects.  Consider that
shade-devstack-functional-ansible is already a job that runs on
changes to shade (it gates shade, even) to verify that they won't
break Ansible.  This effort allows us to easily reverse the direction
so that the same job in the same environment runs on changes to
Ansible.

I also don't think it's a bad thing for OpenStack to continue to
develop direct relationships with its dependencies and consumers.
Sharing a testing environment can encourage that, and seeing a test
result from OpenStack can help reinforce that relationship.

But if any of this sounds like it's edging into OpenLab's mission,
let's take a step back and sort it out."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-02-16 16:29:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> But if any of this sounds like it's edging into OpenLab's mission,
 > let's take a step back and sort it out.

To be clear, I don't think there's any edging going on, simply that there may be questions about when one, when the other. Things that don't directly impact the correctness of this resolution."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-02-16 16:36:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

Based on Jeremy's statement, I am fully for that. I do still have some concerns about confusion between OpenLab's mission and this, and whether some efforts might be better combined, but as far as resolving that it is OK for these things to take place, I'm good."}, {'account_id': 17556, 'date': '2018-02-16 16:55:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

I read this and comments quite a few times and I was just not entirely clear even more so after, 'I am fine with and excited by the idea of leveraging Zuul to test external clients of OpenStack like Ansible and SDKs'. Primarily I just wanted to be able to intelligently respond should I get any questions as well as when talking why OpenLab going forward. Both your comments Jeremy and James helped a lot, thank you."}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-02-19 05:53:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2018-02-20 09:37:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-02-20 19:21:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-02-22 23:43:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 10379, 'date': '2018-02-27 14:19:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-02 17:19:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-03-03 09:09:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck sphinx build error'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-03-03 16:26:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Add resolution about CI for external projects

This resolution is to establish agreement that we think extending
Zuul to run integration tests and report on non-OpenStack projects
(e.g., Ansible, kubernetes, etc.) is in the interest of the community,
and what the scope of such an effort should be.  I plan to follow
it up with specific instructions in the infra-manual describing
the process to set up such testing.

Change-Id: Ia7dc06cade7e436a4df64f4f0d55327ea6c78b81

commit_message:
Drop back to Sphinx 1.6.5

Sphinx 1.7.1 is causing build-openstack-sphinx-docs jobs for some
projects to return "setup.py: error: argument -o/--output-dir is
required" from under PBR. Temporarily roll back to the 1.6.5 version
we were running before the Queens freeze while we look into it.

This partially reverts commit
505ec718c8a0042e4b8cbeeca534d2038aa3c67d.

Change-Id: Ieb5daba9c78c9ca36ac3ec457bad757bc938ece3
Related-Bug: #1753082

When can we take this?'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-02 12:35:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

I *think* we're open for queens updates now but I'm avoiding approiving this in case I'm wrong.

This "patch" release seems a little aggressive to move UI elements around like that it seems more like a minor update (so 2.9.0) with the actual removal being 3.0.0.

Having said that magnum doesn't assert the std-deprecation or stable tags so you can kinda just go ahead and do it anyway.'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2018-03-02 15:39:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Do we need these two as well?
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/540058/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/540057/

You got the whole picture, 2.9.0 would be better but I think this "patch" will affect the release in a more positive way.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-03-02 15:41:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This patches just affect CI, so that does not matter for the release.

You could do 2.9.0 if that makes more sense. Since there hasn't been a newer release that takes that version yet, you can just plan on the first Rocky release of the client to be 2.10.0. Or 3.0.0 if there are big enough changes of course."}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2018-03-02 15:47:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ok then, let's go for 2.9.0, I'll add the final patch for OSC. Tony, Sean, thanks you for looking into this.

To clarify, 2.9.0 will point to a hash from the queens branch, right?"}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-02 16:09:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

> Ok then, let's go for 2.9.0, I'll add the final patch for OSC.
 > Tony, Sean, thanks you for looking into this.

Thanks Spyros

 > To clarify, 2.9.0 will point to a hash from the queens branch,
 > right?

Correct, Update the SHA to c2b32964612ada61af8e6f324bc922f792cff982 and the smever to 2.9.0 and you're good to go.

Dropping my Code-Review as it sounds like a new patchset is coming"}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2018-03-02 17:52:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2018-03-02 18:07:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-03-02 22:20:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17130, 'date': '2018-03-03 05:07:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-03 13:34:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

commit_message:
Ensure all test fixtures in oslo_db.tests are private

Downstream projects have started using the fixtures inside
of oslo_db.tests in response to the deprecations added in
I0163e637ffef6d45d2573ebe29b5438911d01fce.   This was not
the intent of these deprecations, so add messsaging to
this effect and ensure fixtures used by the test suite
itself are noted as private.

Change-Id: I3afe0a440a3ab66904aaecf556948df9d4e16b8e

commit_message:
Bump OpenStack service version

* Bump barbican from 6.0.0.0rc1 to 6.0.0
* Bump blazar from 1.0.0.0rc1 to 1.0.0
* Bump cinder from 12.0.0.0rc1 to 12.0.0
* Bump cloudkitty-dashboard from master to 7.0.0
* Bump cloudkitty from master to 7.0.0
* Bump congress from 7.0.0.0rc1 to 7.0.0
* Bump designate-dashboard from 6.0.0.0rc1 to 6.0.0
* Bump designate from 6.0.0.0rc1 to 6.0.0
* Bump ec2-api from stable-queens to 6.0.0

commit_message:
Fix change_nova_service_state action

The function signature has been changed in 2.53 version[1]
and this patch is required to fix watcher-tempest-plugin.
If all tests are ok, I'll merge it ASAP.

[1]: https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#enable-scheduling-for-a-compute-service

Change-Id: Ie03519dac2a55263e278344fd00f103067f90f27

commit_message:
Populate secure registry set with known secure

That was the original intent of SECURE_REGISTRIES, but it was never
actually used. This change fixes that.

Change-Id: Idd524f91cd1977b34fa1b951683fbd4f74b30b39
Closes-Bug: #1752852

commit_message:
Cleanup for iterators in SegmentedIterable

We had a pair of large, complicated iterators to handle fetching all
the segment data, and they were hard to read and think about. I tried
to break them out into some simpler pieces:

 * one to handle coalescing multiple requests to the same segment

 * one to handle fetching the bytes from each segment

 * one to check that the download isn't taking too long

 * one to count the bytes and make sure we sent the right number

 * one to catch errors and handle cleanup

It's more nesting, but each level now does just one thing.

Change-Id: If6f5cbd79edeff6ecb81350792449ce767919bcc

subject: Make statsd errors correspond to 5xx only
messages:
[{'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-01-23 19:59:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-01-23 20:09:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

probably reasonable, I wonder if anyone can make a convincing argument that 401's should not maintain themselves as a special case?  I think any GET request where we have to open a diskfile is reasonable to count toward GET.timing - but what if we're rejected by ACL or token/auth system without ever going to disk - it must devalue the metric some if there a large amount of rejected requests?  Are errors.timing useful?  Under what conditions do we want to know how *long* the 5XX took?  Is it interesting to know how long 401 or 403 took to respond?

Metrics are hard..."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-01-23 20:12:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-23 20:22:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-01-23 20:25:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

This timing_stats() decorator is only used in the storage servers, not the proxy, so this may or may not be the right way to go.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-01-29 20:16:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Workflow

I think this is the right way to go.

Currently, there's a bunch of 4xx errors that clients can cause that we will count as errors for StatsD purposes. Here's a few:

 * 406 Not Acceptable (account/container listings, but not since listing_formats middleware)

 * 409 Conflict (in container sync and object expiration; in neither case is it an error)

 * 422 Unprocessable Entity (when a client sends the wrong ETag on object PUT)

 * 499 Client Disconnect (when a client is uploading an object and dies partway through)


We can keep adding special-case handling to plug the holes, but I think it's easier for maintenance if we just make all 4xx not count as errors."}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-01-31 03:28:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

Sounds reasonable to me. Maybe pinging other ops (like Romain) to see what they think. Esp if they're using the metrics.

Put down so other thoughts, but out side the scope of this change."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-03 01:44:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

Yeah, sure. Seems like this must be closer to useful stats...

We may want to make sure this shows up in release notes, to explain away a sudden change in graphs on upgrade.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-23 19:59:29.000000000', 'message': 'Make statsd errors correspond to 5xx only

The goal is to make the successful statsd buckets
(e.g. "object-server.GET.timing") have timing information for all the
requests that the server handled correctly, while the error buckets
(e.g. "object-server.GET.errors.timing") have the rest.

Currently, we don't do that great a job of it. We special-case a few
4xx status codes (404, 412, 416) to not count as errors, but we leave
some pretty large holes. If you're graphing errors, you'll see spikes
when client is sending bogus requests (400), failing to
re-authenticate (403) or disconnecting partway through downloads
(499). You'll also see spikes when your drives are unmounted (507) and
when there's bugs that need fixing (500).

This commit makes .errors.timing be just 5xx in the hope that its
graph will be more useful.

Change-Id: I92b41bcbb880c0688c37ab231c19ebe984b18215
'}, {'created': '2018-01-23 20:12:35.000000000', 'message': 'Make statsd errors correspond to 5xx only

The goal is to make the successful statsd buckets
(e.g. "object-server.GET.timing") have timing information for all the
requests that the server handled correctly, while the error buckets
(e.g. "object-server.GET.errors.timing") have the rest.

Currently, we don't do that great a job of it. We special-case a few
4xx status codes (404, 412, 416) to not count as errors, but we leave
some pretty large holes. If you're graphing errors, you'll see spikes
when client is sending bogus requests (400) or failing to
re-authenticate (403). You'll also see spikes when your drives are
unmounted (507) and when there's bugs that need fixing (500).

This commit makes .errors.timing be just 5xx in the hope that its
graph will be more useful.

Change-Id: I92b41bcbb880c0688c37ab231c19ebe984b18215
'}]
commit_message:
Make statsd errors correspond to 5xx only

The goal is to make the successful statsd buckets
(e.g. "object-server.GET.timing") have timing information for all the
requests that the server handled correctly, while the error buckets
(e.g. "object-server.GET.errors.timing") have the rest.

Currently, we don't do that great a job of it. We special-case a few
4xx status codes (404, 412, 416) to not count as errors, but we leave
some pretty large holes. If you're graphing errors, you'll see spikes
when client is sending bogus requests (400) or failing to
re-authenticate (403). You'll also see spikes when your drives are
unmounted (507) and when there's bugs that need fixing (500).

This commit makes .errors.timing be just 5xx in the hope that its
graph will be more useful.

Change-Id: I92b41bcbb880c0688c37ab231c19ebe984b18215

subject: Solve the zombie process problem of Auditor
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1179, 'name': 'Clay Gerrard', 'email': 'clay.gerrard@gmail.com', 'username': 'clay-gerrard'}, {'_account_id': 2622, 'name': 'Samuel Merritt', 'email': 'sam@swiftstack.com', 'username': 'torgomatic'}, {'_account_id': 7847, 'name': 'Alistair Coles', 'email': 'alistairncoles@gmail.com', 'username': 'acoles'}, {'_account_id': 13052, 'name': 'SwiftStack Cluster CI', 'email': 'openstack-ci@swiftstack.com', 'username': 'swiftstack-cluster-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 15343, 'name': 'Tim Burke', 'email': 'tburke@nvidia.com', 'username': 'tburke'}, {'_account_id': 15513, 'name': 'yanwei', 'email': 'yan.wei7@zte.com.cn', 'username': 'vxlinux'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 15513, 'date': '2018-01-15 07:21:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15513, 'date': '2018-01-15 07:46:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 15513, 'date': '2018-01-15 10:47:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

When I ran local unit test,I got py27: commands succeeded. but the log showed the test skipped.:
test_run_parallel_audit (test.unit.obj.test_auditor.TestAuditor) ... SKIP: Large xattrs not supported in `/tmp`. Skipping test

So I will check the code again.'}, {'account_id': 15513, 'date': '2018-01-16 01:26:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15513, 'date': '2018-01-16 01:30:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 15513, 'date': '2018-01-16 01:56:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 15513, 'date': '2018-01-16 01:59:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Published edit on patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 15513, 'date': '2018-01-16 04:04:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Published edit on patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-01-16 21:18:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

This behavior is not what we want.  ZBF scan should be going continually, while the full scans work slowly.  To avoid the time when we're blocked on sleep instead of reaping finished children works in the mainloop we could just drop the sleep and respawn the ZBF scan immediately...

    diff --git a/swift/obj/auditor.py b/swift/obj/auditor.py
    index 611eedd..7fba2cc 100644
    --- a/swift/obj/auditor.py
    +++ b/swift/obj/auditor.py
    @@ -390,8 +390,6 @@ class ObjectAuditor(Daemon):
                     if self.conf_zero_byte_fps and pid == zbf_pid and \
                        len(pids) > 1 and not once:
                         kwargs['device_dirs'] = override_devices
    -                    # sleep between ZBF scanner forks
    -                    self._sleep()
                         zbf_pid = self.fork_child(zero_byte_fps=True, **kwargs)
                         pids.add(zbf_pid)
                     pids.discard(pid)"}, {'account_id': 15513, 'date': '2018-01-18 02:53:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Published edit on patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-01-31 23:47:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15513, 'date': '2018-02-01 09:20:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Published edit on patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 15513, 'date': '2018-02-01 09:25:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15513, 'date': '2018-02-01 12:32:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Published edit on patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-02-09 21:00:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-02 19:50:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

Change makes sense -- it took me longer than I'd like to admit to see that it was the ALL pids piling up, but now that I see it, it's obvious. Tests pop if I back out the change in swift. Great job!"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-02 23:38:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

recheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-15 07:21:16.000000000', 'message': 'Solve the zombie process problem of Auditor

Change-Id: I61c766aa2a1c4bad0247a44a8e78ef38d9f3ae47
'}, {'created': '2018-01-15 07:46:45.000000000', 'message': "Solve the zombie process problem of Auditor

As the bug 1743310 reported,if we list the swift processes ,we will see 
a zombie process every one minute.The zombie processes numbers may be 
more than one.

The related code as follows:
swift/obj/auditor.py:386~397

            while pids:
                pid = os.wait()[0]
                # ZBF scanner must be restarted as soon as it finishes
                # unless we're in run-once mode
                if self.conf_zero_byte_fps and pid == zbf_pid and \
                   len(pids) > 1 and not once:
                    kwargs['device_dirs'] = override_devices
                    # sleep between ZBF scanner forks
                    self._sleep()
                    zbf_pid = self.fork_child(zero_byte_fps=True, **kwargs)
                    pids.add(zbf_pid)
                pids.discard(pid)
               
The pids list includes a zbf pid and one or more pids with 
mode (ALL - parallel, objectXXX).If the zbf process is the last one 
finishedÔºåthen the second zbf process will not be forked„ÄÇConverselyÔºå
the zbf process will be forked again,before the fork procedure,the main 
process will sleep for self.interval seconds,30 seconds by default,during 
the self.interval time,if a non zbf process finished,this process will 
become a zombie,because the main process is in sleep.

From this code segment,we see the zbf process must be finished after all
the other processes.So I think we can fork the zbf process outside the 
while loopÔºåand the trigger condition is determined in the while loop.

Closes-Bug: #1743310

Change-Id: I61c766aa2a1c4bad0247a44a8e78ef38d9f3ae47
"}, {'created': '2018-01-16 01:26:03.000000000', 'message': 'Solve the zombie process problem of Auditor

Change-Id: I61c766aa2a1c4bad0247a44a8e78ef38d9f3ae47

            if self.conf_zero_byte_fps and pid == zbf_pid and \
               len(pids) > 1 and not once:
                kwargs['device_dirs'] = override_devices
                # sleep between ZBF scanner forks
                self._sleep()
                zbf_pid = self.fork_child(zero_byte_fps=True, **kwargs)
                pids.add(zbf_pid)
            pids.discard(pid)

The pids list includes a zbf pid and one or more pids with mode 
(ALL - parallel, objectXXX).If the zbf process is the last one 
finishedÔºåthen the second zbf process will not be forked„ÄÇConverselyÔºå

process will sleep for self.interval seconds,30 seconds by default,

            pid = os.wait()[0]
            # ZBF scanner must be restarted as soon as it finishes
            # unless we're in run-once mode
            if self.conf_zero_byte_fps and pid == zbf_pid and \
               len(pids) > 1 and not once:
                kwargs['device_dirs'] = override_devices
                # sleep between ZBF scanner forks
                self._sleep()
                zbf_pid = self.fork_child(zero_byte_fps=True, **kwargs)
                pids.add(zbf_pid)
            pids.discard(pid)

The pids list includes a zbf pid and one or more pids with mode 
(ALL - parallel, objectXXX).If the zbf process is the last one 
finishedÔºåthen the second zbf process will not be forked„ÄÇConverselyÔºå 
the zbf process will be forked again,before the fork procedure,the main 
process will sleep for self.interval seconds,30 seconds by default,
during the self.interval time,if a non zbf process finished,this process 
will become a zombie,because the main process is in sleep.

From this code segment,we see the zbf process must be finished after 
all the other processes.So I think we can fork the zbf process outside 
the while loopÔºåand the trigger condition is determined in the while 
loop.

Closes-Bug: #1743310

Change-Id: I61c766aa2a1c4bad0247a44a8e78ef38d9f3ae47

commit_message:
Solve the zombie process problem of Auditor

As the bug 1743310 reported,if we list the swift processes ,we will 
see a zombie process every one minute.The zombie processes numbers may 
be more than one. 

The related code as follows: swift/obj/auditor.py:386~397

        while pids:
            pid = os.wait()[0]
            # ZBF scanner must be restarted as soon as it finishes
            # unless we're in run-once mode
            if self.conf_zero_byte_fps and pid == zbf_pid and \
               len(pids) > 1 and not once:
                kwargs['device_dirs'] = override_devices
                # sleep between ZBF scanner forks
                self._sleep()
                zbf_pid = self.fork_child(zero_byte_fps=True, **kwargs)
                pids.add(zbf_pid)
            pids.discard(pid)

The pids list includes a zbf pid and one or more pids with mode 
(ALL - parallel, objectXXX).If the zbf process is the last one 
finishedÔºåthen the second zbf process will not be forked.ConverselyÔºå 
the zbf process will be forked again,before the fork procedure,the main 
process will sleep for self.interval seconds,30 seconds by default,
during the self.interval time,if a non zbf process finished,this process 
will become a zombie,because the main process is in sleep.

In this solution,we move the sleep from whileloop to the subprocess,and
the main process will not be blocked in whileloop,so the subprocess
will be recovered in time.

Closes-Bug: #1743310

Change-Id: I61c766aa2a1c4bad0247a44a8e78ef38d9f3ae47

commit_message:
Adds Overcloud Upgrade class and entry points for major upgrade

This further refactors the update/upgrades cli and separates
the update and upgrade code. This adds the overcloud_upgrade.py
which defines the UpgradePrepare and UpgradeRun. The entry
points are now:

  openstack overcloud upgrade prepare --container-registry-file ...

For the no-op heat stack update to refresh stack outputs and

  openstack overcloud upgrade run --nodes foo --playbooks all

For running all the upgrade ansible playbooks. A corresponding
converge sub-command will be introduced in a subsequent patch.

Change-Id: I1880e8f546df8d509871ba3b4f02877e95c611c8

[{'created': '2018-03-02 15:41:40.000000000', 'message': 'Fix exporting workload with n/a success_rate to es

ElasticSearch exporter assumes that success_rate from workload stats
is a string with numeric value from 0 to 100 + '%' char in the end.

It is not always True. For example in case of failure in contexts, the
workload inself will have "n/a" success rate.

This patch covers the case

Change-Id: If8380febc65f6f92331ef1137aa83301a81200a9
'}]
commit_message:
Fix exporting workload with n/a success_rate to es

ElasticSearch exporter assumes that success_rate from workload stats
is a string with numeric value from 0 to 100 + '%' char in the end.

It is not always True. For example in case of failure in contexts, the
workload inself will have "n/a" success rate.

This patch covers the case

Change-Id: If8380febc65f6f92331ef1137aa83301a81200a9

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-20 17:02:30.000000000', 'message': 'Add firewall chain configuration

Adds the ability to specify firewall chains via heat templates.
Additionally newer versions of docker have switched to updating
the FORWARD chain to DROP by default. Neutron needs this to be
ACCEPT by default. This change adds the ability to specify
firewall chains via templates.

commit_message:
Add firewall chain configuration

Adds the ability to specify firewall chains via heat templates.
Additionally newer versions of docker have switched to updating
the FORWARD chain to DROP by default. Neutron needs this to be
ACCEPT by default. This change adds the ability to specify
firewall chains via templates.

Depends-On: Ib75f97748540b9162d76c9c189d3ca7e082b3784
Change-Id: I15ec9216013a1b0b935dcd1f5bc8281348777189
Related-Bug: #1750194
(cherry picked from commit a1ec856e61532daa49f38683857918fd2cc561aa)

commit_message:
Ensure FORWARD is ACCEPT by default

Newer versions of docker have switched to updating the FORWARD chain to
be DROP by default. This causes issues with the deployment. Update the
FORWARD chains to be ACCEPT by default.

Depends-On: Ib75f97748540b9162d76c9c189d3ca7e082b3784
Closes-Bug: #1750194

Change-Id: I93be7138e6a61cf3aadf19f53097d67469befc17
(cherry picked from commit da31c6e5baaf4abf01a6c2232a0dbac2513f0e06)

so fix that here also.

subject: Stop showing results with passwords
messages:
[{'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2018-02-16 18:10:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2018-02-16 18:17:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2018-02-16 18:19:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-02-16 18:44:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2018-02-16 18:50:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

We can try that, though I'm ok with difficult debugging (vs passwords), but I understand your concern :)"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2018-02-16 20:28:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Though I'm intrigued, why would using loop_control affect passwords and such getting dumped?"}, {'account_id': 22165, 'date': '2018-02-17 06:36:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

IMHO, 
1. this commit is not stop show the password(auth) info, but all output, it is not a good idea.
2. operator will rum aciton on deploy node, he will configure the auth password, name and so on, he can get everything if he want,  No Display make no sense for him,
3. why the other projects(like cinder) not need do this change?

if I'm wrong, please tell me, I will remove my -1"}, {'account_id': 19316, 'date': '2018-02-20 08:24:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

In my opinion, this should be fixed in the ansible module, i dont like hide all the output because make things impossible to debug.

mysql_db module probably already set no_log to login_password, but in our implementation (module who calls a module) dont.

We have to find a way to add no_log to passwords in called modules.'}, {'account_id': 7488, 'date': '2018-02-21 06:41:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2018-02-22 04:36:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ah cool I didn't know about that.

So part of the issue I'm having hear is that for some reason people think it's ok to have passwords at *any* point (even if it makes debugging harder). I think we should try to do some of the suggestions here and see how they work; but if your system is dumping out passwords left and right the first thing that should IMHO **not** come to mind is how hiding them will make debugging harder... it should be that your clouds (and automation) is now open up to malicious users and that's bad and I'm not even a really good operator or whatever, this is just common sense... First you stop the hemorrhaging, then you treat the wounds, not the other way around..."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2018-02-22 04:38:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

As for '2. operator will rum aciton on deploy node, he will configure the auth password, name and so on, he can get everything if he want, No Display make no sense for him,'

No this is not how things should work, operator should not be running any actions himself and in ideal world operator should not have access to all the passwords and machines; he should be using automation that does it and operator should do something more productive with his time instead."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2018-03-02 21:33:26.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Moving to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/546467/'}]
